Award.AwardTitle: Life Cycles of Basaltic Magma Mushes: The Dynamic Controls on Unlocking and Mixing
Award.AbstractNarration:
The transport of heat and mass from the Earth's deep interior to the surface by magmatism (volcanism) creates the Earth's crust and strongly conditions the atmosphere and biosphere. However the processes are almost entirely unseen, and the dynamics must be inferred from sparse observations. These observations have converged on a picture for magma systems such that they exist in a mushy, or crystal-rich and quasi-static, state for much of their thermal lifetime. This has been documented in a variety of geological environments from ocean islands and large igneous provinces, to convergent margin volcanic chains, to mid-ocean ridge systems.

Paradoxically, it has also been confirmed that these mushes can be rapidly mobilized and complexly mixed, sometimes just prior to eruption. And when the crystal mushes are preserved as large plutonic bodies, they display evidence of complex fluid and granular rheological regimes that co-existed simultaneously. Our aim is to identify the fundamental dynamic templates that produce these reoccurring processes in Nature. We will do this by employing the unification of crystal-chemical data and novel computational fluid dynamics modeling tools to reveal the templates which control of emergence of and character of distinct magmatic episodes. Our field area will be the 1868 lava flows of Mauna Loa, Hawaii, where we will identify distinct populations of magmatic products, and by utilizing the discrete element method computational fluid dynamics approach we can create synthetic populations and identify what the dynamic controls are on their occurance.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Life Cycles of Basaltic Mushes: The Dynamic Controls on Unlocking and Mixing

 

Intellectual Merit:

 

The purpose of those research was to create a computational infrastructure, tightly coupled to a corresponding field project, to reveal the physics behind diverse ways that a crystal mush produces a complex crystal cargo. This is significant because virtually all estimates of the time scales of mixing and fractionation are obtained from the crystal record. Hence without a high-fidelity understanding of what produces those timescales, progress has been stalled.

 

Our specific research activities involved developing a discrete element-computational fluid dynamics (DEM-CFD) model, the first time such a model has been deployed in magmatic studies. The purpose was to illuminate the local controls on magma mixing following reintrusion. This work revealed that granular processes manifest a surprising complexity, involving both frictional and fluid modes of behavior. This was heretofore unappreciated, but has now been recognized in field examples widely, including large granite bodies. This work also allowed us to produce synthetic crystal zoning populations to compare with those found in nature. We also undertook two field campaigns, one in Hawaii, one in Argentina, to create crystal populations from simple process that we could then compare with those produced by simulation.

 

The DEM-CFD work was successful, and expanded well beyond its original scope with publications devoted to a general treatise on the behavior of crystal-rich magmas to detailed work on the role of crystal-scale processes like lubrication. From this a much broader, but also deeply informed, picture emerged as to the diverse expressions of the physics of crystal mush

.

The creation of Jupyter notebooks and publications also reconsidered the ways that processes are recorded in crystals that respond to changes in intensive variables. These include various kinetics models demonstrating how well crystals may (or may not) record their history. It provided an important cautionary test-bed to explore the ergodicity of the crystal record.

 

Broader Impacts:

 

The broader impacts were twofold, first the dissemination of the information described above which has also received notice in the mechanical and earthquake engineering communities, and secondly by the training of students from the high school to the graduate level. This was done with a combination of invited talks at the Dept. and international meetings level, by publishing in high impact peer-reviewed journals, and by posting instructional animations on YouTube. Graduate education and training was a key part of the broader impacts and involved two students, who also participated in our ?Rockin? Out? outreach program to local high schools. They also had oral and poster presentations at AGU, one winning a best presentation award. The material developed under this grant was also used in both undergraduate and graduate curriculum.

 

Grant funds were also used to support a postdoc and the mentoring activities associated with that contributed to advancing the professional development of an early career female scientist.
